LeadDev: Why good teams rely on bad workarounds
Messy workarounds aren’t a symptom of careless teams, but of delivery pipelines that aren’t fit for purpose. Here’s how to root out the unnecessary friction.

With Francine Pilot, Steve Fenton, Simone Casciaroli, and Ryn Daniels.

Even the most well-intentioned delivery pipeline can lead to unintended workarounds. You may have selected best-in-class tooling and defined best practices, but no two teams or projects are the same. When delivery pressure builds, teams find inventive ways to bypass systems that aren’t serving them, leading to increased rework and risk.

For engineering managers and platform engineers, the challenge is to identify where teams need more options and find ways to provide them without abandoning the appropriate constraints.

In this panel discussion, we’re lifting the lid on why and where the most common workarounds crop up in delivery pipelines, and the modern aspects of software delivery that enable you to stop them in their tracks.

Key takeaways:

- The most common delivery workarounds and why they happen
- Rooting out unnecessary sources of developer friction
- Allowing more choice in tool selection while maintaining robust delivery practices

Feel free to stop me for a chat about DevOps, Continuous Delivery, metrics, and deployment automation if you spot me walking around the conference floor.

## Talk synopsis

I spent years taking on development teams and transforming them into high performers and the team members were never the problem. This session leans on years of "transformations" and a decade of research to provide some concrete steps you can take to do the same.

The DORA research reveals what elite performers do differently, but knowing what to improve and actually making improvements are different challenges. This session cuts through the complexity to focus on the handful of high-impact capabilities you can start using today.

You'll learn:

- Where to start for the biggest returns
- How to sequence your efforts
- How to build momentum toward elite performance levels without trying to transform everything at once

Proving that DevOps is here to stay, events in New York and London to level up your practice.

Catch my talk “What if DevOps was really simple?” at 11 am on March 13, 2026. Screen 2 / Track 2.

Building trust from source to ship

Most software pipelines focus on writing code and deploying it, but the real risk is what happens in between. Join Cloudsmith and Octopus Deploy to learn how to build trust in software artifacts and enforce security and compliance through your Golden Path.

With Gwen Burchell, Cristian Garcia, and Steve Fenton.

Most software pipelines focus on writing code and deploying it, but the real risk is what happens in between. Join Cloudsmith and Octopus Deploy to learn how to build trust in software artifacts and enforce security and compliance through your Golden Path.

Things you'll learn

- Why “what we built is what we deployed” is a board-level concern
- Where the biggest trust gaps exist in modern SDLCs
- What artifact and delivery trust really mean
- How to design Golden Paths that enforce trust, not just convenience
- What a real chain of custody looks like in Kubernetes platforms
